abstract_summ: This study proved that HCoV-NL63 was undergoing continuous mutation and has the potential to cause severe lower respiratory disease in humans.2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) is widespread in China and other countries.We studied seven patients who were workers at the market, and collected bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) from one patient who exhibited a severe respiratory syndrome including fever, dizziness and cough, and who was admitted to Wuhan Central Hospital on December 26th 2019.This outbreak highlights the ongoing capacity of viral spill-over from animals to cause severe disease in humans.The widespread existence of these bat-carried or -released viruses might have an easier time in breaking through human defenses when harsh winter makes human bodies more vulnerable.Here we report a cluster of HCoV-NL63 cases with severe lower respiratory tract infection that arose in Guangzhou, China, in 2018.
title_summ: Discovery of a subgenotype of human coronavirus NL63 associated with severe lower respiratory tract infection in China, 2018Does infection of 2019 novel coronavirus cause acute and/or chronic sialadenitis?Complete genome characterisation of a novel coronavirus associated with severe human respiratory disease in Wuhan, ChinaPotential Factors Influencing Repeated SARS Outbreaks in ChinaHistory is repeating itself, a probable zoonotic spillover as a cause of an epidemic: the case of 2019 novel Coronavirus.
title_abstract_phrases: This study proved that HCoV-NL63 was undergoing continuous mutation and has the potential to cause severe lower respiratory disease in humans.Discovery of a subgenotype of human coronavirus NL63 associated with severe lower respiratory tract infection in China, 2018Human coronavirus NL63 (HCoV-NL63) is primarily associated with common cold in children, elderly and immunocompromised individuals.Complete genome characterisation of a novel coronavirus associated with severe human respiratory disease in Wuhan, ChinaEmerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, such as SARS, MERS, Zika and highly pathogenic influenza present a major threat to public health1–3.We studied seven patients who were workers at the market, and collected bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) from one patient who exhibited a severe respiratory syndrome including fever, dizziness and cough, and who was admitted to Wuhan Central Hospital on December 26th 2019.Potential Factors Influencing Repeated SARS Outbreaks in ChinaWithin last 17 years two widespread epidemics of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) occurred in China, which were caused by related coronaviruses (CoVs): SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
